content: The Act may be cited as the "Lavender Offense Victim Exoneration Act of 2017" or the "LOVE Act of 2017". During the Lavender Scare in the 1950s and 1960s, over 1,000 Department of State employees were wrongfully dismissed for alleged homosexuality. The Department of State claimed their sexual orientation made them security risks. Many patriotic Americans were also barred from joining the Department. During the Lavender Scare in the 1950s and 1960s, over 1,000 Department of State employees were wrongfully dismissed for alleged homosexuality, citing security risks. Patriotic Americans were also prevented from joining the Department due to a screening process targeting individuals who appeared to be gay or lesbian, influenced by congressional investigations and pressure. Between 1950 and 1969, the Department of State reported on the number of homosexuals fired each year due to congressional complaints about sympathies to Communism. The "Lavender Scare" led to wrongful dismissals of over 1,000 employees, with investigations into gay personnel continuing into the 1990s. In 1994, Secretary of State Warren Christopher prohibited discrimination based on sexual orientation in the Department of State. President Clinton signed Executive Order 13087 in 1998 to bar discrimination on this basis. Secretary of State John Kerry apologized in 2017 for the impact of the "Lavender Scare" on individuals. The Department reaffirms its commitment to diversity and inclusion for all employees, including the LGBTI community, impacted by past discriminatory practices. SEC. 3. DIRECTOR GENERAL REVIEW. The Director General of the Foreign Service and Director of Human Resources, in consultation with the Historian of the Department of State, will review employee terminations since January 1, 1950, to identify wrongful terminations based on sexual orientation. A report compiling this information will be made publicly available within 270 days of the enactment of the Act, including historical statements from Department of State officials. The Department of State and Congress implemented policies leading to the termination of employees based on their sexual orientation, as indicated by historical statements. The Secretary of State will review the consistency of Director General's reviews under section 3 and submit reports to Congress. A Reconciliation Board will be established. The Secretary of State will establish an independent Reconciliation Board within the Office of Civil Rights to review reports on employees fired during the "Lavender Scare". The Board will contact affected employees or their families to inform them of the inappropriate terminations. The Department of State offers to change employment records for those affected by discrimination based on sexual orientation. A senior-level contact will receive testimony from employees or family members who experienced discrimination or termination due to their sexual orientation. The Department of State will review claims of discrimination based on sexual orientation within 150 days, regardless of paperwork availability. The Board offers a grievance process for former employees who believe they were terminated due to their sexual orientation. The Board will terminate 5 years after the enactment of this Act, responsible for providing relevant information on each claim to prove no wrongful termination. The Board will terminate 5 years after the enactment of this Act, responsible for providing relevant information on each claim to prove no wrongful termination. SEC. 6. ISSUANCE OF APOLOGY. Secretary of State Kerry apologized on January 9, 2017 for not providing equal protections to LGBTI families of State Department officers. He emphasized his support for the LGBTI community and appointed a Special Envoy for the Human Rights of LGBTI Persons in 2015. In 2015, the first Special Envoy for the Human Rights of LGBTI Persons was appointed by the Secretary of State Kerry, who apologized for past discrimination against LGBTI individuals by the Department of State. The Department reaffirmed its commitment to diversity and inclusion for all employees. Congress offers a formal apology for its role in the "Lavender Scare" and similar policies at the Department of State, which were influenced by congressional investigations into the "sex perversion of Federal employees" and reports on the employment of "moral perverts by Government Agencies". Establishment of permanent exhibit on the Lavender Scare. The Secretary of State will collaborate with a public-private partnership to create a permanent exhibit on the "Lavender Scare" at the United States Diplomacy Center. The exhibit must be installed within a year, provide access to relevant reports, and display oral history material. The exhibit at the United States Diplomacy Center on the "Lavender Scare" must display oral testimony from employees or family members affected by discriminatory policies. SEC. 8. GUIDANCE ON ISSUING VISAS. The Secretary of State must submit a report to Congress within 100 days of this Act, addressing countries denying visas to Foreign Service personnel's spouses based on sexual orientation. Recommendations may include ending visa reciprocity with such countries to ensure all spouses receive visas regardless of sexual orientation. SEC. 9. ESTABLISHMENT OF ADVANCEMENT BOARD. The Secretary of State will establish an Advancement Board within the Department of State to address issues faced by LGBTQI Foreign Service employees and their families. The Board will hear testimony from these employees regarding discrimination based on sexual orientation and will issue reports annually for 5 years. The Advancement Board will submit annual reports to Congress for 5 years based on employee testimony, including recommendations to prevent discrimination based on sexual orientation. The reports will be private and accessible only to Members of Congress, their staff, and the Advancement Board.
